books.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas

chapters.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:1
verses.text: Sermon Against Auxentius on the Giving Up of the Basilicas.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:2
verses.text: To calm the anxiety of the people over the imperial decree, he lays his answer before them, and adds that he did not go to the consistory, because he was afraid of losing the basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:3
verses.text: Then, first challenging his opponents to a discussion in the church, he says that he is not terrified at their weapons; and also, after recalling his answer on the subject of the sacred vessels, declares that he is ready for the contest.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:4
verses.text: The will of God, he maintains, cannot be frustrated, nor can His protection be overcome, yet He is ready too to suffer in His servants.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:5
verses.text: Since he has not already been taken before this, it is plain that the heretics are causing this disturbance for no reason whatever.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:6
verses.text: Next, after applying Naboth's history and Christ's entry into Jerusalem to the present state of affairs, he censures Auxentius' cruel law, answers the Arians' objections, and states that he will gladly discuss the matter in the presence of the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:7
verses.text: Auxentius, he adds, has been already condemned by the pagans, whom he had chosen to sit as judges, as he had been condemned by Paul and by Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:8
verses.text: The heretic had forgotten the year before, when he had made the same appeal to Caesar; and the Arians, in stirring up ill-will against the servants of Christ, are much worse than the Jews: for the Church does not belong to Caesar, but displays the image of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:9
verses.text: Then adding to these a few more words on his answer and his hymns, he declares that he is not disobedient, that the Emperor is a son of the Church, and that Auxentius is worse than a Jew.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:10
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:11
verses.text: I see that you are unusually disturbed, and that you are closely watching me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:12
verses.text: I wonder what the reason is? Is it that you saw or heard that I had received an imperial order at the hands of the tribunes, to the effect that I was to go hence, whither I would, and that all who wished might follow me? Were you afraid that I should desert the Church and forsake you in fear for my own safety? But you could note the message I sent, that the wish to desert the Church had never entered my mind; for I feared the Lord of the universe more than an earthly emperor; and if force were to drag me from the Church, my body indeed could be driven out, but not my mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:13
verses.text: I was ready, if he were to do what royal power is wont to do, to undergo the fate a priest has to bear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:14
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:15
verses.text: Why, then, are you disturbed? I will never willingly desert you, though if force is used, I cannot meet it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:16
verses.text: I shall be able to grieve, to weep, to groan; against weapons, soldiers, Goths, my tears are my weapons, for these are a priest's defence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:17
verses.text: I ought not, I cannot resist in any other way; but to fly and forsake the Church is not my way; lest any one should suppose I did so from fear of some heavier punishment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:18
verses.text: You yourselves know that I am wont to show respect to our emperors, but not to yield to them, to offer myself freely to punishment, and not to fear what is prepared for me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:19
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:20
verses.text: Would that I were sure the Church would never be given over to heretics.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:21
verses.text: Gladly would I go to the Emperor's palace, if this but fitted the office of a priest, and so hold our discussion in the palace rather than the church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:22
verses.text: But in the consistory Christ is not wont to be the accused but the judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:23
verses.text: Who will deny that the cause of faith should be pleaded in the church? If any one has confidence let him come hither; let him not seek the judgment of the Emperor, which already shows its bias, which clearly proves by the law that is passed that he is against the faith; neither let him seek the expected goodwill of certain people who want to stand well with both sides.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:24
verses.text: I will not act in such a way as to give any one the chance of making money out of a wrong to Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:25
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:26
verses.text: The soldiers around, the clash of the arms wherewith the church is surrounded, do not alarm my faith, but they disquiet me from fear that in keeping me here you might meet with some danger to your lives.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:27
verses.text: For I have learnt by now not to be afraid, but I do begin to have more fear for you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:28
verses.text: Allow, I beg you, your bishop to meet his foes.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:29
verses.text: We have an adversary who assails us, for our adversary "the devil goeth about, as a roaring lion, seeking whom he may devour," as the Apostle said.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:30
verses.text: He has received, no doubt, he has received (we are not deceived, but warned of this) the power to tempt in this wise, lest I might perhaps by the wounds of my body be drawn away from the earnestness of my faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:31
verses.text: You have read how the devil tempted holy Job in these many ways, and how at last he sought and obtained power to try his body, which he covered with sores.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:32
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:33
verses.text: When it was suggested that I should give up the vessels of the Church, I gave the following answer: I will willingly give up whatever of my own property is demanded, whether it is estates, or house, or gold, or silver—anything, in fact, which is in my power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:34
verses.text: But I cannot take aught away from the temple of God; nor can I give up what I have received to guard and not to give up.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:35
verses.text: In doing this I am acting for the Emperor's good, for it would neither be right for me to give it up, nor for him to receive it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:36
verses.text: Let him listen to the words of a free-spoken bishop, and if he wishes to do what is best for himself, let him cease to do wrong to Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:37
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:38
verses.text: These words are full of humility, and as I think of that spirit which a bishop ought to show towards the Emperor.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:39
verses.text: But since "our contest is not against flesh and blood, but also" (which is worse) "against spiritual wickedness in high places," that tempter the devil makes the struggle harder by means of his servants, and thinks to make trial of me by the wounds of my flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:40
verses.text: I know, my brethren, that these wounds which we receive for Christ's sake are not wounds that destroy life, but rather extend it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:41
verses.text: Allow, I pray, the contest to take place.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:42
verses.text: It is for you to be the spectators.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:43
verses.text: Reflect that if a city has an athlete, or one skilled in some other noble art, it is eager to bring him forward for a contest.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:44
verses.text: Why do you refuse to do in a more important matter what you are wont to wish in smaller affairs? He fears not weapons nor barbarians who fears not death, and is not held fast by any pleasures of the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:45
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:46
verses.text: And indeed if the Lord has appointed me for this struggle, in vain have you kept sleepless watch so many nights and days.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:47
verses.text: The will of Christ will be fulfilled.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:48
verses.text: For our Lord Jesus is almighty, this is our faith: and so what He wills to be done will be fulfilled, and it is not for us to thwart the divine purpose.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:49
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:50
verses.text: You heard what was read to-day: The Saviour ordered that the foal of an ass should be brought to Him by the apostles, and bade them say, if any one withstood them: "The Lord hath need of him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:51
verses.text: What if now, too, He has commanded that foal of an ass, that is, the foal of that animal which is wont to bear a heavy burden, as man must, to whom is said: "Come unto Me all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest; take My yoke upon you, for it is easy;" what if, I say, He has commanded that foal to be brought to Him now, sending forth those apostles, who, having put off their body, wear the semblance of the angels unseen by our eyes? If withstood by any, will they not say: The Lord hath need of him? If, for instance, love of this life, or flesh and blood, or earthly intercourse (for perhaps we seem pleasing to some), were to withstand them? But he who loves me here, would show his love much more if he would suffer me to become Christ's victim, for "to depart and be with Christ is much better, though to abide in the flesh is more needful for you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:52
verses.text: There is nothing therefore for you to fear, beloved brethren.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:53
verses.text: For I know that whatever I may suffer, I shall suffer for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:54
verses.text: And I have read that I ought not to fear those that can kill the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:55
verses.text: And I have heard One Who says: "He that loseth his life for My sake shall find it".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:56
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:57
verses.text: Wherefore if the Lord wills, surely no one will resist.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:58
verses.text: And if as yet He delay my struggle, what do you fear? It is not bodily guardianship but the Lord's providence that is wont to fence in the servant of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:59
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:60
verses.text: You are troubled because you have found the double doors open, which a blind man in seeking his chamber is said to have unfastened.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:61
verses.text: In this you learn that human watchfulness is no defence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:62
verses.text: Behold! one who has lost the gift of sight has broken through all our defences, and escaped the notice of the guards.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:63
verses.text: But the Lord has not lost the guard of His mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:64
verses.text: Was it not also discovered two days ago, as you remember, that a certain entrance on the left side of the basilica was open, which you thought had been shut and secured? Armed men surrounded the basilica, they tried this and the other entrance, but their eyes were blinded so that that could not see the one that was open.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:65
verses.text: And you know well that it was open many nights.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:66
verses.text: Cease, then, to be anxious; for that will take place which Christ commands and which is for the best.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:67
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:68
verses.text: And now I will put before you examples from the Law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:69
verses.text: Eliseus was sought by the king of Syria; an army had been sent to capture him; and he was surrounded on all sides.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:70
verses.text: His servant began to fear, for he was a servant, that is, he had not a free mind, nor had he free powers of action.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:71
verses.text: The holy prophet sought to open his eyes, and said: "Look and see how many more are on our side than there are against us".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:72
verses.text: And he beheld, and saw thousands of angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:73
verses.text: Mark therefore that it is those that are not seen rather than those that are seen that guard the servants of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:74
verses.text: But if they guard you, they do it in answer to your prayers: for you have read that those very men, who sought Eliseus, entered Samaria, and came to him whom they desired to take.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:75
verses.text: Not only were they unable to harm him, but they were themselves preserved at the intercession of the man against whom they had come.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:76
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:77
verses.text: The Apostle Peter also gives you an example of either case.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:78
verses.text: For when Herod sought him and took him, he was put into prison.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:79
verses.text: For the servant of God had not got away, but stood firm without a thought of fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:80
verses.text: The Church prayed for him, but the Apostle slept in prison, a proof that he was not in fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:81
verses.text: An angel was sent to rouse him as he slept, by whom Peter was led forth out of prison, and escaped death for a time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:82
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:83
verses.text: And Peter again afterwards, when he had overcome Simon, in sowing the doctrine of God among the people, and in teaching chastity, stirred up the minds of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:84
verses.text: And when these sought him, the Christians begged that he would withdraw himself for a little while.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:85
verses.text: And although he was desirous to suffer, yet was he moved at the sight of the people praying, for they asked him to save himself for the instruction and strengthening of his people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:86
verses.text: Need I say more? At night he begins to leave the town, and seeing Christ coming to meet him at the gate, and entering the city, says: Lord, whither goest Thou? Christ answers: I am coming to be crucified again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:87
verses.text: Peter understood the divine answer to refer to his own cross, for Christ could not be crucified a second time, for He had put off the flesh by the passion of the death which He had undergone; since: "In that He died, He died unto sin once, but in that He liveth, He liveth unto God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:88
verses.text: So Peter understood that Christ was to be crucified again in the person of His servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:89
verses.text: Therefore he willingly returned; and when the Christians questioned him, told them the reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:90
verses.text: He was immediately seized, and glorified the Lord Jesus by his cross.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:91
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:92
verses.text: You see, then, that Christ wills to suffer in His servants.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:93
verses.text: And what if He says to this servant, "I will that he tarry, follow thou Me," and wishes to taste the fruit of this tree? For if His meat was to do the will of His Father, so also is it His meat to partake of our sufferings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:94
verses.text: Did He not, to take an example from our Lord Himself,—did He not suffer when He willed, and was He not found when He was sought? But when the hour of His passion had not yet come, He passed through the midst of those that sought Him, and though they saw Him they could not hold Him fast.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:95
verses.text: This plainly shows us that when the Lord wills, each one is found and taken, but because the time is put off, he is not held fast, although he meets the eyes of those who seek him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:96
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:97
verses.text: And did not I myself go forth daily to pay visits, or go to the tombs of the martyrs? Did I not pass by the royal palace both in going and returning? Yet no one laid hands on me, though they had the intention of driving me out, as they afterwards gave out, saying, Leave the city, and go where you will.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:98
verses.text: I was, I own, looking for some great thing, either sword or fire for the Name of Christ, yet they offered me pleasant things instead of sufferings; but Christ's athlete needs not pleasant things but sufferings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:99
verses.text: Let no one, then, disturb you, because they have provided a carriage, or because hard words, as he thinks them, have been uttered by Auxentius, who calls himself bishop.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:100
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:101
verses.text: Many stated that assassins had been despatched, that the penalty of death had been decreed against me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:102
verses.text: I do not fear all that, nor am I going to desert my position here.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:103
verses.text: Whither shall I go, when there is no spirit that is not filled with groans and tears; when throughout the Churches Catholic bishops are being expelled, or if they resist, are put to the sword, and every senator who does not obey the decree is proscribed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:104
verses.text: And these things were written by the hand and spoken by the mouth of a bishop who, that he might show himself to be most learned, omitted not an ancient warning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:105
verses.text: For we read in the prophet that he saw a flying sickle.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:106
verses.text: Auxentius, to imitate this, sent a flying sword through all cities.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:107
verses.text: But Satan, too, transforms himself into an angel of light, and imitates his power for evil.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:108
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:109
verses.text: Thou, Lord Jesus, hast redeemed the world in one moment of time: shall Auxentius in one moment slay, as far as he can, so many peoples, some by the sword, others by sacrilege? He seeks my basilica with bloody lips and gory hands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:110
verses.text: Him to-day's chapter answers well: "But unto the wicked said God: Wherefore dost thou declare My righteousness?" That is, there is no union between peace and madness, there is no union between Christ and Belial.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:111
verses.text: You remember also that we read to-day of Naboth, a holy man who owned his own  vineyard, being urged on the king's request to give it up.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:112
verses.text: When the king after rooting up the vines intended to plant common herbs, he answered him: "God forbid that I should give up the inheritance of my fathers".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:113
verses.text: The king was grieved, because what belonged by right to another had been refused him on fair grounds, but had been unfairly got by a woman's device.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:114
verses.text: Naboth defended his vines with his own blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:115
verses.text: And if he did not give up his vineyard, shall we give up the Church of Christ?  18.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:116
verses.text: Was the answer that I gave then contumacious? For when summoned I said: God forbid that I should give up the inheritance of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:117
verses.text: If Naboth gave not up the inheritance of his fathers, shall I give up the inheritance of Christ? And I added further: God forbid that I shall give up the inheritance of my fathers, that is, the inheritance of Dionysius, who died in exile in the cause of the faith; the inheritance of the Confessor Eustorgius, the inheritance of Mysocles and of all the faithful bishops of bygone days.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:118
verses.text: I answered as a bishop ought to answer: Let the Emperor act as an emperor ought to.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:119
verses.text: He must take away my life rather than my faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:120
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:121
verses.text: But to whom shall I give it up? Today's lesson from the Gospel ought to teach us what is asked for and by whom it is asked.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:122
verses.text: You have heard read that when Christ sat upon the foal of an ass, the children cried aloud, and the Jews were vexed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:123
verses.text: At length they spoke to the Lord Jesus, bidding Him to silence them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:124
verses.text: He answered: "If these should hold their peace, the stones will cry out".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:125
verses.text: Then on entering the temple, He cast out the money-changers, and the tables, and those that sold doves in the temple of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:126
verses.text: That passage was read by no arrangement of mine, but by chance; but it is well fitted to the present time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:127
verses.text: The praises of Christ are ever the scourges of the unfaithful.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:128
verses.text: And now when Christ is praised, the heretics say that sedition is stirred up.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:129
verses.text: The heretics say that death is being prepared for them, and truly they have their death in the praises of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:130
verses.text: For how can they bear His praises, Whose weakness they maintain.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:131
verses.text: And so to-day, when Christ is praised, the madness of the Arians is scourged.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:132
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:133
verses.text: The Gerasenes could not bear the presence of Christ; these, worse than the Gerasenes, cannot endure the praises of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:134
verses.text: They see boys singing of the glory of Christ, for it is written: "Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings Thou hast perfected praise".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:135
verses.text: They mock at their tender age, so full of faith, and say: "Behold, why do they cry out?" But Christ answers them: "If these should hold their peace, the stones will cry out," that is, the stronger will cry out, both youths and the more mature will cry out, and old men will cry out; these stones now firmly laid upon that stone of which it is written: "The stone which the builders rejected is become the head of the corner".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:136
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:137
verses.text: Invited, then, by these praises, Christ enters His temple, and takes His scourge and drives the money-changers out of the temple.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:138
verses.text: For He does not allow the slaves of money to be in His temple, nor does He allow those to be there who sell seats.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:139
verses.text: What are seats but honours? What are the doves but simple minds or souls that follow a pure and clear faith? Shall I, then, bring into the temple him whom Christ shuts out? For he who sells dignities and honours will be bidden to go out.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:140
verses.text: He will be bidden to go out who desires to sell the simple minds of the faithful.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:141
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:142
verses.text: Therefore, Auxentius is cast out.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:143
verses.text: Mercurius is shut out.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:144
verses.text: The portent is one, the names are two! That no one might know who he was, he changed his name so as to call himself Auxentius, because there had been here an Arian bishop, named Auxentius.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:145
verses.text: He did this to deceive the people over whom the other had had power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:146
verses.text: He changed his name, but he did not change his falseness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:147
verses.text: He puts off the wolf, yet puts on the wolf again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:148
verses.text: It is no help to him that he has changed his name; whatever happens he is known.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:149
verses.text: He is called by one name in the parts of Scythia, he is called by another here.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:150
verses.text: He has a name for each country he lives in.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:151
verses.text: He has two names already, and if he were to go elsewhere from here, he will have yet a third.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:152
verses.text: For how will he endure to keep a name as a proof of such wickedness? He did less in Scythia, and was so ashamed that he changed his name.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:153
verses.text: Here he has dared to do worse things, and will he be ready to be betrayed by his name wherever he goes? Shall he write the death warrant of so many people with his own hand, and yet be able to be unshaken in mind?  23.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:154
verses.text: The Lord Jesus shut a few out of His temple, but Auxentius left none.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:155
verses.text: Jesus with a scourge drove them out of His temple,  Auxentius with a sword; Jesus with a scourge, Mercurius with an axe.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:156
verses.text: The holy Lord drives out the sacrilegious with a scourge; the impious man pursues the holy with a sword.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:157
verses.text: Of him you have well said to-day: Let him take away his laws with him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:158
verses.text: He will take them, although he is unwilling; he will take with him his conscience, although he takes no writing; he will take with him his soul inscribed with blood although he will not take a letter inscribed with ink.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:159
verses.text: It is written: "Juda, thy sin is written with a pen of iron and with the point of a diamond, and it is graven upon thy heart," that is, it is written there, whence it came forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:160
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:161
verses.text: Does he, a man full of blood and full of murder, dare to make mention to me of a discussion? He who thinks that they whom he could not mislead by his words are to be slain with the sword, giving bloody laws with his mouth, writing them with his hand, and thinking that the law can order a faith for man to hold.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:162
verses.text: He has not heard what was read to-day: "That a man is not justified by the works of the law," or "I, through the law, am dead to the law, that I may live unto God," that is, by the spiritual law he is dead to the carnal interpretation of the law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:163
verses.text: And we, by the law of our Lord Jesus Christ, are dead to this law, which sanctions such perfidious decrees.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:164
verses.text: The law did not gather the Church together, but the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:165
verses.text: For the law is not by faith, but "the just man lives by faith".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:166
verses.text: Therefore, faith, not the law, makes a man just, for justice is not through the law, but through the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:167
verses.text: But he who casts aside his faith and pleads for that the claims of the law, bears witness that he is himself unjust; for the just man lives by faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:168
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:169
verses.text: Shall any one, then, follow this law, whereby the Council of Ariminum is confirmed, wherein Christ was said to be a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:170
verses.text: But say they: "God sent forth His Son, made of a woman, made under the law".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:171
verses.text: And so they say "made," that is, "created".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:172
verses.text: Do they not consider these very words which they have brought forward; that Christ is said to have been made, but of a woman; that is, He was "made" as regards his birth from a Virgin, Who was begotten of the Father as regards His divine generation? Have they read also to-day, "that Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us"? Was Christ a curse in His Godhead? But why He is called a curse the Apostle tells us, saying that it is written: "Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree," that is, He Who in his flesh bore our flesh, in His body bore our infirmities and our curses, that He might crucify them; for He was not cursed Himself, but was cursed in thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:173
verses.text: So it is written elsewhere: "Who knew no sin, but was made sin for us, for He bore our sins, that he might destroy them by the Sacrament of His Passion".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:174
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:175
verses.text: These matters, my brethren, I would discuss more fully with him in your presence; but knowing that you are not ignorant of the faith, he has avoided a trial before yon, and has chosen some four or five heathen to represent him, if that is he has chosen any, whom I should like to be present in our company, not to judge concerning Christ, but to hear the majesty of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:176
verses.text: They, however, have already given their decision concerning Auxentius, to whom they gave no credence as he pleaded before them day by day.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:177
verses.text: What can be more of a condemnation of him than the fact, that without an adversary he was defeated before his own judges? So now we also have their opinion against Auxentius.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:178
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:179
verses.text: And that he has chosen heathen is rightly to be condemned; for he has disregarded the Apostle's command, where he says: "Dare any of you, having a matter against another, go to law before the unjust and not before the saints? Do ye not know the saints shall judge the world?" And below he says: "Is it so, that there is not a wise man among you, who can judge between heathen? But brother goeth to law with brother, and that before the unbelievers".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:180
verses.text: You see, then, that what he has introduced is against the Apostle's authority.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:181
verses.text: Do you decide, then, whether we are to follow Auxentius or Paul as our master.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:182
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:183
verses.text: But why speak of the Apostle, when the Lord Himself cries through the prophet: "Hearken unto Me, My people, ye who know judgment, in whose heart is My law".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:184
verses.text: God says: "Hearken unto Me, My people, ye that know judgment".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:185
verses.text: Auxentius says: Ye know not judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:186
verses.text: Do you see how he condemns God in you, who rejects the voice of the heavenly oracle: "Hearken unto Me, My people," says the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:187
verses.text: He says not, "Hearken, ye Gentiles," nor does He say, "Hearken, ye Jews".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:188
verses.text: For they who had been the people of the Lord  have now become the people of error, and they who were the people of error have begun to be the people of God; for they have believed on Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:189
verses.text: That people then judges in whose heart is the divine, not the human law, the law not written in ink, but in the spirit of the living God; not set down on paper, but stamped upon the heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:190
verses.text: Who then, does you a wrong, he who refuses, or he who chooses to be heard by you?  29.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:191
verses.text: Hemmed in on all sides, he betakes himself to the wiles of his fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:192
verses.text: He wants to stir up ill-will on the Emperor's side, saying that a youth, a catechumen ignorant of the sacred writings, ought to judge, and to judge in the consistory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:193
verses.text: As though last year when I was sent for to go to the palace, when in the presence of the chief men the matter was discussed before the consistory, when the Emperor wished to seize the basilica, I was cowed then at the sight of the royal court, and did not show the firmness a bishop should, or departed with diminished claims.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:194
verses.text: Do they not remember that the people, when they knew I had gone to the palace, made such a rush that they could not resist its force; and all offered themselves to death for the faith of Christ as a military officer came out with some light troops to disperse the crowd? Was not I asked to calm the people with a long speech? Did I not pledge my word that no one should invade the basilica of the church? And though my services were asked for to do an act of kindness, yet the fact that the people came to the palace was used to bring ill-will upon me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:195
verses.text: They wish to bring me to this now again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:196
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:197
verses.text: I recalled the people, and yet I did not escape their ill-will, which ill-will, however, I think we ought rather to tempt than fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:198
verses.text: For why should we fear for the Name of Christ? Unless perchance I ought to be troubled because they say: "Ought not the Emperor to have one basilica, to which to go, and Ambrose wants to have more power than the Emperor, and so refuses to the Emperor the opportunity of going forth to church?" When they say this, they desire to lay hold of my words, as did the Jews who tried Christ with cunning words, saying: "Master, is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar or not?" Is ill-will always stirred up against the servants of God on Caesar's account, and does impiety make use of this with a view to starting a slander, so as to shelter itself under the imperial name? and can they say that they do not share in the sacrilege of those whose advice they follow?  31.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:199
verses.text: See how much worse than the Jews the Arians are.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:200
verses.text: They asked whether He thought that the right of tribute should be given to Caesar; these want to give to Caesar the right of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:201
verses.text: But as these faithless ones follow their author, so also let us answer as our Lord and Author has taught us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:202
verses.text: For Jesus seeing the wickedness of the Jews said to them: Why tempt ye Me? show Me a penny.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:203
verses.text: When they had given it, He said: "Whose image and superscription hath it?" They answered and said: Caesar's.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:204
verses.text: And Jesus says to them: "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:205
verses.text: So, too, I say to these who oppose me: Show me a penny.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:206
verses.text: Jesus sees Caesar's penny and says: Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:207
verses.text: Can they in seizing the basilicas of the church offer Caesar's penny?  32.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:208
verses.text: But in the church I only know of one Image, that is the Image of the unseen God, of Which God has said: "Let us make man in Our image and Our likeness;" that Image of Which it is written, that Christ is the Brightness of His glory and the Image of His Person.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:209
verses.text: In that Image I perceive the Father, as the Lord Jesus Himself has said: "He that seeth Me seeth the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:210
verses.text: For this Image is not separated from the Father, which indeed has taught me the unity of the Trinity, saying: "I and My Father are One," and again: "All things that the Father hath are Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:211
verses.text: Also of the Holy Spirit, saying that the Spirit is Christ's, and has received of Christ, as it is written: "He shall receive of Mine, and shall declare it unto you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:212
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:213
verses.text: How, then, did we not answer humbly enough? If he demand tribute, we do not refuse it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:214
verses.text: The lands of the Church pay tribute.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:215
verses.text: If the Emperor wants the lands, he has the power to claim them, none of us will interfere.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:216
verses.text: The contributions of the people are amply sufficient for the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:217
verses.text: Do not stir up ill-will in the matter of the lands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:218
verses.text: Let them take them if it is the Emperor's will.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:219
verses.text: I do not give them, but I do not refuse them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:220
verses.text: They ask for gold.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:221
verses.text: I can say: Silver and gold I do not ask for.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:222
verses.text: But they stir up ill-will because gold is spent.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:223
verses.text: I am not afraid of such ill-will as this.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:224
verses.text: I have dependents.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:225
verses.text: My dependents are Christ's poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:226
verses.text: I know how to collect this treasure.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:227
verses.text: On that they may even charge me with this crime, that I have spent money on the poor! and if they make the charge that I seek for defence at their hands, I do not deny it; nay, I solicit it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:228
verses.text: I have my defence, but it consists in the prayers of the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:229
verses.text: The blind and the lame, the weak and the old, are stronger than hardy warriors.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:230
verses.text: Lastly, gifts to the poor make God indebted to us, for it is written: "He that giveth to the poor, lendeth to God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:231
verses.text: The guards of warriors often do not merit divine grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:232
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:233
verses.text: They declare also that the people have been led astray by the strains of my hymns.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:234
verses.text: I certainly do not deny it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:235
verses.text: That is a lofty strain, and there is nothing more powerful than it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:236
verses.text: For what has more power than the confession of the Trinity which is daily celebrated by the mouth of the whole people? All eagerly vie one with the other in confessing the faith, and know how to praise in verse the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:237
verses.text: So they all have become teachers, who scarcely could be disciples.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:238
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:239
verses.text: What could show greater obedience than that we should follow Christ's example, "Who, being found in fashion as a man, humbled Himself and became obedient even unto death?" Accordingly He has freed all through His obedience.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:240
verses.text: "For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of One shall many be made righteous".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:241
verses.text: If, then, He was obedient, let them receive the rule of obedience: to which we cling, saying to those who stir up ill-will against us on the Emperor's side: We pay to Caesar what is Caesar's, and to God what is God's.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:242
verses.text: Tribute is due to Caesar, we do not deny it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:243
verses.text: The Church belongs to God, therefore it ought not to be assigned to Caesar.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:244
verses.text: For the temple of God cannot be Caesar's by right.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:245
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:246
verses.text: That this is said with respectful feeling for the Emperor, no one can deny.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:247
verses.text: For what is more full of respect than that the Emperor should be called the son of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:248
verses.text: As it is said, it is said without sin, since it is said with the divine favour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:249
verses.text: For the Emperor is within the Church, not above it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:250
verses.text: For a good emperor seeks the aid of the Church and does not refuse it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:251
verses.text: As I say this with all humility, so also I state it with firmness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:252
verses.text: Some threaten us with fire, sword, exile; we have learnt as servants of Christ not to fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:253
verses.text: To those who have no fear, nothing is ever a serious cause of dread.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:254
verses.text: Thus too is it written: "Arrows of infants their blows have become".

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:255
Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:256
verses.text: A sufficient answer, then, seems to have been given to their suggestion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:257
verses.text: Now I ask them, what the Saviour asked: "The baptism of John, was it from heaven or men?" The Jews could not answer Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:258
verses.text: If the Jews did not make nothing of the baptism of John, does Auxentius make nothing of the baptism of Christ? For that is not a baptism of men, but from heaven, which the angel of great counsel has brought to us, that we might be justified to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Sermon Against Auxentius on Giving Up of the Basilicas 1:259
verses.text: Wherefore, then, does Auxentius hold that the faithful ought to be rebaptized, when they have been baptized in the name of the Trinity, when the Apostle says: "One faith, one baptism"? And wherefore does he say that he is man's enemy, not Christ's, seeing that he despises the counsel of God and condemns the baptism which Christ has granted us to redeem our sins.
